Name: 10 cognitive biases to avoid in User Research (and how to avoid them)
Exerpt: Cognitive biases have become quite popular in mainstream culture in the last decade, thanks to books like Thinking Fast and Slow and Predictably Irrational. Along with human centered approaches, it has also gained quite a lot of prominence in Experience/Business design.

Name: 8-Point Grid: Vertical Rhythm
Exerpt: The 8-point grid is a powerful system for creating consistent and visually appealing user interfaces (UIs). This post is about how to establish vertical rhythm and set typography in an 8pt grid system.

Name: A Comprehensive Guide To Product Design
Exerpt: (This is a sponsored article.) What is a product? Until recently, the term was used only in relation to something material and often found in a retail store. Nowadays, it is coming to mean digital products as well. Apps and websites are modern products.

Name: A Designer’s Guide to Working in Tech

Name: A guide to understanding what makes a typeface accessible
Exerpt: A guide to understanding what makes a typeface accessibleAnd how to make more informed design decisions.

Name: A Muggle’s Guide to Product Design
Exerpt: What I’m about to share with you is neither profound nor true. But then again, things aren’t always what they seem.  Insights like these are normally reserved for witches and wizards, but just this once, I insist you be let in on our little secret.

Name: A UX Career is a Business Career
Exerpt: There’s this venn diagram that I’m sure you’ve seen many times. It’s in just about every article written about UX design because it does a good job summing up the field at a glance. Here’s a version of it:

Name: Accessibility drives aesthetics
Exerpt: Image descriptions are in the alt text. There’s an article circulating that claims accessibility and aesthetics are at odds with each other, creating a paradox that forces us to compromise. Here’s why I find that belief completely and utterly false:

Name: Content: the design system element you forgot
Exerpt: This was the question my ex-colleague Jonathon Colman raised this question on LinkedIn.

Name: Design for Humanity
Exerpt: In 1950, the American psychologist Harry Harlow conducted an experiment that separated infant monkeys from their mothers just a few hours after birth. Each monkey was isolated in a cage and given two dummy mothers.

Name: Design Systems articles on building and maintaining design systems
Exerpt: Using 'styled-components` and `styled-system` to support customization within a 3rd party application while also preventing unwanted changes.

Name: Designing accessible products
Exerpt: In a diverse world like ours, we cannot simply assume that all the users access and experience digital products in the same way. That's when accessibility becomes a crucial element of the design process that has inclusion and diversity in mind.

Name: Designing Better Design Documentation
Exerpt: Various documents — reports, briefs, maps, guidelines — usually are the way designers communicate the results of their work to teammates or clients. One doesn’t simply collect all the design data in one place and call it a day.

Name: Designing with AI
Exerpt: At Facebook, AI is everywhere.  Behind the scenes, AI helps make Facebook smarter and easier to use.

Name: Don’t take design critique as an insult
Exerpt: Design critique sessions are nothing new. They are an integral part of the design process, and over the last years modern companies have found smart and efficient ways to incorporate these sessions into everything they design and build.

Name: GRAPHIC DESIGN ARCHIVE
Exerpt: Brought to you by Webflow Explore key moments in graphic design history like the middle ages, punk publishing, and swiss design, meet the makers, and see how design has shaped culture.

Name: Great interfaces are made of good typography
Exerpt: Digital interfaces make a huge impact in our lives. We frequently use websites or digital applications to accomplish certain goals. Indeed, when interacting with an interface, we are surrounded by typography and our experience is driven by the words and messages we read and understand.

Name: Guidelines for thoughtful product design
Exerpt: Over the last few years I’ve been working on a set of guidelines that both my team members and students can use to help judge if a product is well designed. No product is an island. Good product design acknowledges that.

Name: How Quantitative UX Research Differs from Data Analytics
Exerpt: When we introduce ourselves as quantitative UX researchers, people often get curious about the “quantitative” part of our title. One question they ask is how our work is similar to, or different from, the work of product analysts or product data scientists.

Name: How to design v1 products and live to talk about it
Exerpt: You roll up your sleeves, crack your knuckles, and sit down at your laptop to finally design that thing you’ve been thinking about. But as you stare at Sketch or Figma or Illustrator or Photoshop or Maya… you realize you have no idea where to start.

Name: How to understand your impact in the brave new world of product design
Exerpt: It’s time to change a lot of the dialog we have in the design industry. It’s time for us to start thinking about the impact our designs have on the world. We’ve spent far too long thinking about how cool something is.

Name: Intro to The 8-Point Grid System
Exerpt: As a designer you’ve probably heard the term grid whether you’re designing a website, a magazine, or a mobile app. We have grids for all sorts of content arrangements. We use column grids to align content horizontally. Baseline grids to vertically align bodies of text.

Name: Product Design Exercises We Use At WeWork Interviews
Exerpt: The design community is lucky to have so many great resources like Dribbble, Behance, Daily UI etc. These resources allow to see others visual work, show yours and get feedback.

Name: Psychology and product design
Exerpt: As product designers, we try to create products that are designed for humans. We try to solve their problems and create a better experience by making better understandability and discoverability in products we design.

Name: Should Designers Code?
Exerpt: There’s a recurring debate in our industry over whether or not designers should write code. Some developer will pose the question on Twitter, then pundits, practitioners, and gurus answer it. Everyone has an opinion, tempers flare, then people agree to disagree, and the discussion subsides.

Name: Spacing, Grids and Layouts
Exerpt: The organization of space is key to every great design. Spatial systems, grids, and layouts provide rules that give your designs a consistent rhythm, constrain decision making, and help teams stay aligned. This foundational scaffolding is a requirement for all design systems.

Name: The best YouTube channels for designers and developers
Exerpt: I just recently realized how much time I spend on YouTube everyday. To be more precise, about 50 minutes every single day. About three years ago I started developing the habit of opening the YouTube Subscriptions page every day to check out new videos from the channels I had subscribed to.

Name: The Golden Age of UX is Over
Exerpt: When I started AJ&Smart in 2011, UX Design was still so misunderstood that I spent the next 3 years just explaining to my clients (while also defining it to myself) what it actually was and why it was valuable.

Name: The Holloway Guide to Equity Compensation
Exerpt: Equity compensation is the practice of granting partial ownership in a company in exchange for work.

Name: The Power of Visioning
Exerpt: Visioning allows us to both understand product usage, and the larger task of getting to know a new domain or industry.

Name: The Vandalisation of ‘UX’
Exerpt: Etymologists have long been aware of the effect known as semantic drift — how the meanings of phrases can change over time. For example, mouse and bookmark now make sense as concepts in computers as well as their root meaning.

Name: Things I (honestly) don’t want to see in your portfolio
Exerpt: Tools change every few months. We might have different view of what the word “skill” means.

Name: Understanding UX Competitor Analysis
Exerpt: Design isn’t just about the creative process. The important part of any project begins before any sketches are drawn. It starts with the research — the competitor analysis that guides every subsequent decision and helps shape the final product.

Name: UX Writing vs Copywriting
Exerpt: Traditionally, how things have typically progressed is that the design team would design a product and send it over to the the development team who would then build it.

Name: What I know after a decade in design
Exerpt: 2018 will be the year that marks my first decade as a designer. Wow… crazy. Sometimes I still feel like a junior designer, but when I look back on myself ten years ago, I can see just how much I’ve learned.  I want to share with you some of the things I’ve learned over the years.

Name: What it takes to be a Product Designer
Exerpt: I analysed 30 different Product Designer roles from some of the most well-respected companies in the world. Why? There’s a common question that keeps popping up in the conversations that I’m having; what is a Product Designer? I think I’m one… but, maybe I’m not…?! Or maybe I am…

Name: What Your Engineering Team Wants in a UX Designer
Exerpt: Have you ever been around a group of creative types when the conversation turns to what coders don’t do and don’t understand? It happens more often and more casually than I’d like to admit. It’s nonsense, and I don’t stand for such talk in the name of shooting the breeze.

Name: Why you should be writing UX case studies
Exerpt: Better design speaks for itself. Results are established in how well they communicate their core values to their users and in turn how successful the product is deemed to be. So having said this, it’s easy to forget the approach to reach such a result.

Name: Your Body Text Is Too Small
Exerpt: Body text is the key component in communicating the main bulk of a message or story, and it’s probably the most important element on a website, even if people sometimes read just the headlines. The majority of websites are still anywhere in the range of 15–18px.
